            $body.removeClass('desktop');

        } else {
            window.mobile = false;
            window.desktop = true;
            $body.removeClass('mobile');
            $body.addClass('desktop');
        }
    }

    let media = window.matchMedia('(max-width: 800px)');
    media.addEventListener('change', changed_mobile);
    changed_mobile(media);
</script>

<script>
    $(function() {
        let $mobile_header = $('.mobile-header');
        let $burger = $('.mobile-header .burger');
        let $menu_overlay = $('.mobile-header .menu-overlay');
        let $return = $('.mobile-header .return');

        let active = false;
        let level = 0;
        let $menu_root = $('.mobile-header .menu-root');

        let overlay_height = window.innerHeight - $('.mobile-header .top')[0].scrollHeight
            - $('.mobile-header .menu-bar')[0].scrollHeight;
        $('.mobile-header .menu-overlay').css({'height': overlay_height});

        $burger.on('click', function() {
            if (active) {
                active = false;
                $menu_overlay.fadeOut(200);
                $return.css({'opacity': 0});
                $mobile_header.css({'background-color': '#212E3B'});
                $burger.removeClass('active');
                $('body').css({'overflow': 'inherit'});
            } else {
                active = true;
                $menu_overlay.fadeIn(200);
                $return.css({'opacity': 1});
                $mobile_header.css({'background-color': '#121F29'});
                $burger.addClass('active');
                $('body').css({'overflow': 'hidden'});
            }
        });
        
        $return.on('click', function () {
            if (level < 1) return;

            $menu_root.find('> li > ul '.repeat(level)).removeClass('menu-active');
            level -= 1;
            $menu_root.css({'transform': 'translateX(' + (-level * 100) + 'vw)'});
            
            if (level === 0) {
                $return.css({'display': 'none'});
            }
        });
    
        $menu_root.on('click', function (event) {
            let $target = $(event.target);
            if ($target.hasClass('menu-button')) {
                level += 1;
                $menu_root.find('> li > ul '.repeat(level)).removeClass('menu-active');
                $target.children('ul').first().addClass('menu-active');
                $menu_root.css({'transform': 'translateX(' + (-level * 100) + 'vw)'});
                $return.css({'display': 'flex'});
            }
        });
        
        let last_scroll = window.scrollY, top = 0, max = $mobile_header.outerHeight();
        $(window).on('scroll', function() {
            top += last_scroll - window.scrollY;

            if (top < -max) top = -max;
            if (top > 0) top = 0;

            $mobile_header.css({'top': top + 'px'});
            last_scroll = window.scrollY;
        });
    });
</script>

<script>
    $(function() {
        let open = false;
        let active = null;
        let closeTimer = null;
        
        $('.desktop-header .menu-root .menu-button').on('mouseover', function() {
            let new_active = $(this).data('menu');
            
            if (active && active !== new_active) {
                $('.desktop-header .slide-menu-' + active).css({'display': 'none'});
                $('.desktop-header .menu-button').removeClass('active');
            }
            
            $('.desktop-header .slide-menu-' + new_active).css({'display': 'inherit'});
            $(this).addClass('active');
            active = new_active;
            
            let height = $('.desktop-header .slide-menu-' + active)[0].scrollHeight + 'px';
            $('.desktop-header .slide-menu-overlay').css({'height': height});
            
            if (!open) {
                open = true;
                $('.desktop-header').addClass('active');
                $('.desktop-header .slide-menu-overlay').css({'display': 'inherit'});
                
                if (height === '0px') {
                    height = $('.desktop-header .slide-menu-' + active)[0].scrollHeight + 'px';
                    $('.desktop-header .slide-menu-overlay').css({'height': height});
                }
            }
        });
        
        $('.desktop-header').on('mouseover', function() {
           clearTimeout(closeTimer);
        });
        
        $('.desktop-header').on('mouseout', function() {
            if (open) {
                closeTimer = setTimeout(function() {
                    $('.desktop-header').removeClass('active');
                    $('.desktop-header .menu-button').removeClass('active');
                    
                    $('.desktop-header .slide-menu-overlay').css({'height': '0'});

                    let _active = active;
                    setTimeout(function() {
                        $('.desktop-header .slide-menu-' + _active).css({'display': 'none'});
                    }, 250);
                    
                    active = null;
                    open = false;
                }, 400);
            }
        });
    });
</script>

	<div class="container">

						<article>
														
							<figure class="content">
                                <div class="s-p-co-l">
								    <h2><img loading="lazy" class="alignnone" src="../../../../uploads/2017/10/tofsee-image-1.jpg" alt="logo" width="746" height="417" /></h2>
<p>Tofsee is a multi-purpose malware with wide array of capabilities &#8211; it can mine bitcoins, send emails, steal credentials, perform DDoS attacks, and more. All of this is possible because of its modular nature.</p>
<p>We have already published about Tofsee/Gheg a few months ago &#8211; <a href="https://www.cert.pl/en/news/single/tofsee-en">https://www.cert.pl/en/news/single/tofsee-en</a>. Reading or at least skimming it is probably required to fully understand this post. Note that it is meant as an extension of that research, focusing on plugin functionality that we previously ignored. We will shortly summarize each plugin and highlight its most important features.</p>
<p>The post is rather long &#8211; for the impatient, list of hashes and table of contents in one:</p>
<table>
<thead>
<tr>
<th>Resource Id</th>
<th>DLL name</th>
<th>DLL MD5 hash</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>1</td>
<td><a href="#1-ddosrdll">ddosR.dll</a></td>
<td><span style="font-family: monospace">fbc7eebe4a56114e55989e50d8d19b5b</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>2</td>
<td><a href="#2-antibotdll">antibot.dll</a></td>
<td><span style="font-family: monospace">a3ba755086b75e1b654532d1d097c549</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>

<h2>1. ddosR.dll</h2>
<p>Original filename: <span style="font-family: monospace">p:\cmf5\small2\plugins\plg_ddos\ddos.cpp</span></p>
<p>This plugin can perform DDOS attacks. Implemented attacks are not very complicated, for example request spamming (HTTP Flood):</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/853f411a5f9806cbc551e28e931aa21c.js"></script></p>
<p>Or plain old SYN flood (using <span style="font-family: monospace">PassThru</span> driver, aka <span style="font-family: monospace">grabb</span> module).</p>
<p>We haven&#8217;t observed any DDoS activity from Tofsee yet, so this plugin is probably not used by the botmaster.</p>
<p>Configuration from the C&#038;C for this plugin is very simple:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/13b539d37092f640e4170919e0cdfd99.js"></script></p>
<p>The binary contains a lot of strings, what simplifies analysis greatly:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/f3c2b8d123d73ed03e7745adab31aa81.js"></script></p>
<h2>2. antibot.dll</h2>
<p>Original filename: <span style="font-family: monospace">z:\cmf5\small2\plugins\plg_antibot\plugin.cpp</span></p>
<p>Now, this is an interesting plugin, because it removes other malware from victim&#8217;s computer.</p>
<p>It can:</p>
<ul class="cert_li_before"></p>
<ul>
<li>enumerate processes and kill ones that may be dangerous (search by configured names)</li>
<li>search <span style="font-family: monospace">SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\Browser Helper Objects</span> registry branch, and remove bad browser helper objects</li>
<li>enumerate mutexes and kill processes that own them (search by mutex names).</li>
</ul>
<p></ul>
<p>List of browser helper objects removed by this module (downloaded from C&#038;C):</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/5d6e55feca424e5e180d4c5e8f6ef6a7.js"></script></p>
<h2>3. snrpR.dll</h2>
<p>Original filename: <span style="font-family: monospace">p:\\cmf5\\small2\\plugins\\plg_sniff\\sniff.cpp</span></p>
<p>Related config section:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/4a2d1b7e68fa3c3ec6bbafb19f8ecdfc.js"></script></p>
<p>Communication is sniffed and replaced using PassThru driver (accessible through named pipe <span style="font-family: monospace">&#8220;\\\\.\\PassThru&#8221;</span>)</p>
<ul class="cert_li_before"></p>
<ul>
<li>
<p><strong>mail.sniff</strong> enables stealing mail addresses from incoming e-mails. Mail addresses are stolen from &#8220;From&#8221; and &#8220;To&#8221; fields. It also looks for entities &#8220;%40&#8243;,&#8221;#64&#8243;,&#8221;#064&#8221; in content (looking for &#8220;@&#8221; char).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>ftp.sniff</strong> and <strong>pop.sniff</strong> enables POP3 and FTP credentials stealing. The plugin is looking for &#8220;user&#8221; and &#8220;pass&#8221; protocol commands, gets authentication data and sends through Passthru driver.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>mail.replace</strong> functionality replaces incoming e-mails using a specified template (stored in &#8216;mailbody&#8217; key of config)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p></ul>
<p>Template example that we received (despite this function being turned off right now):</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/39cf0d9a5740d68f3553bcf6bfec3f74.js"></script></p>
<p>It leaves original &#8220;From&#8221; and &#8220;To&#8221; headers (<span style="font-family: monospace">%FROM_LINE</span>, <span style="font-family: monospace">%TO_LINE</span>), has the ability to leave original subject (<span style="font-family: monospace">%SUBJ</span>, <span style="font-family: monospace">%_SUBJ</span>), and original timestamps (<span style="font-family: monospace">%DATE</span>, <span style="font-family: monospace">%P5DATE</span>, <span style="font-family: monospace">%M5DATE</span>).</p>
<h2>4. proxyR.dll</h2>
<p>Original filename: <span style="font-family: monospace">p:\\cmf5\\small2\\plugins\\plg_proxy\\plugin.cpp</span></p>
<p>This plugin listens for TCP connections on <span style="font-family: monospace">0.0.0.0:1080</span> and provides multithreaded SOCKS proxy server. The sample we analyzed identifies itself in <span style="font-family: monospace">Proxy-Agent</span> HTTP header as <span style="font-family: monospace">WinRoute Pro/4.1</span>.</p>
<p>Traffic is redirected to addresses specified at a proxy_cfg section, separately for each region.</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/bd8a9966f6b9eae770f99a5f0e5b04e8.js"></script></p>
<p>Addresses are specified as a reference to a <span style="font-family: monospace">work_srv</span> list or directly.</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/d78ada95d4985ac66d79c06ba281fd3d.js"></script></p>
<p>In <span style="font-family: monospace">proxy_cfg</span> we can also find some defined timeouts for a socket.</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/2609c31d4965a029ae84c370b27cdf68.js"></script></p>
<p>When any value is missing in configuration, binary has some sane defaults inside.</p>
<p>Plugin also adds port mapping using UPNP, disguising itself as Skype:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/db9b0498c55d44da0e676dde040ca234.js"></script></p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/608a18aee7ba8e6b95269a5b6581a718.js"></script></p>
<p>Strings from the binary give a little more insight about the purpose of this plugin:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/5452c1f171008a64cd21aba0d7311835.js"></script></p>
<h2>6. protect.dll</h2>
<p>Original filename: <span style="font-family: monospace">z:\cmf5\small2\plugins\plg_protect\plugin.cpp</span></p>
<p>This plugin downloads and installs malicious service in system:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/a12c3bdf70ca9b53f11ae9e3f3575563.js"></script></p>
<p>Malicious service binary is obfuscated with &#8220;state-of-the-art encryption algorithm&#8221; &#8211; i.e. negating every byte:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/62694b8d561f856a999fea86b1261c1d.js"></script></p>
<p>Md5 of decrypted backdoor = <span style="font-family: monospace">49642f1d1b1673a40f5fa6263a66d056</span>. This file is protected by packer, and it&#8217;s the only packed binary that we observed during our analysis of Tofsee &#8211; it suggests that the binary could&#8217;ve been created by another actor and reused in Tofsee.</p>
<h2>7. locsR.dll</h2>
<p>Original filename: <span style="font-family: monospace">z:\cmf5\cmf5\small2\plugins\plg_locs\plg.cpp</span></p>
<p>This plugin steals network credentials for Microsoft Outlook:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/39d1ad63f7b21ff66be5cce2a2e32c20.js"></script></p>
<p>After extracting them from the registry, they are decrypted and used to send more emails. Additionally, it generates email in form <span style="font-family: monospace">[computer name]@mail.ru</span> and attempts to send emails using it (with raw SMTP protocol).</p>
<p>Strings from binary:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/65973230a8c95df911aeddbd543d3224.js"></script></p>
<h2>10. hostR.dll</h2>
<p>This is HTTP server plugin. It masquerades as <span style="font-family: monospace">Apache/2.2.15 (Win32)</span>. It can serve files, probably for other bots.</p>
<p>It is able to blacklist some IPs &#8211; probably security analysts (for example Forcepoint and Google are banned).</p>
<p>Configuration for this module, fetched from the C&#038;C:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/0fa585c58255e27519091e05ec2bdb92.js"></script></p>
<h2>11. text.dll</h2>
<p>Original filename: <span style="font-family: monospace">p:\cmf5\small2\plugins\plg_text\plg_text.cpp</span></p>
<p>Very short plugin, it is able to process email templates downloaded from C&#038;C.</p>
<h2>12. smtp.dll</h2>
<p>Very important module &#8211; it generates and sends emails. It&#8217;s probably biggest module and code is rather complicated sometimes.</p>
<p>Most interesting thing about it is the fact that it uses its own dedicated scripting language for generating messages. Script example, received from C&#038;C:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/a29b67bb4eef6f88128b69a3eca74420.js"></script></p>
<p>If someone recognizes this as a real scripting language, we&#8217;d be grateful for the information. We have never seen something like this, so we analyzed interpreter of this language.</p>
<p>The syntax is rather simple, but very assemblish and primitive. We hope that malware authors are generating this scripts from a higher level language because writing something like this must really hurt one&#8217;s sanity ;].</p>
<p>A lot of <span style="font-family: monospace">opcodes</span> are supported &#8211; take a look at this (simplified) parsing function for example:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/65b2e2ad0702638143fc7a94d292c65a.js"></script></p>
<p>We didn&#8217;t reverse all of them, but few most important ones are:</p>
<ul class="cert_li_before"></p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: monospace">C ip:port</span> &#8211; <span style="font-family: monospace">C</span>onnect</li>
<li><span style="font-family: monospace">L lbl</span> &#8211; Create <span style="font-family: monospace">L</span>abel <span style="font-family: monospace">lbl</span>.</li>
<li><span style="font-family: monospace">J lbl</span> &#8211; <span style="font-family: monospace">J</span>ump to label <span style="font-family: monospace">lbl</span>.</li>
<li><span style="font-family: monospace">v name value</span> &#8211; Create <span style="font-family: monospace">v</span>ariable <span style="font-family: monospace">name</span> and assign value <span style="font-family: monospace">value</span>.</li>
<li><span style="font-family: monospace">W text</span> &#8211; <span style="font-family: monospace">W</span>rite something to output &#8211; in this case to final email.</li>
<li><span style="font-family: monospace">I lbl condition</span> &#8211; <span style="font-family: monospace">I</span>f <span style="font-family: monospace">condition</span> is satisfied than jump to <span style="font-family: monospace">lbl</span></li>
</ul>
<p></ul>
<p>Additionally wrapping text in <span style="font-family: monospace">&#8220;&#8221;&#8221;</span> allows for newlines and escape sequences in it, and <span style="font-family: monospace">__v(XX)__</span> is a variable interpolation.</p>
<p>Again, few from the most interesting strings from that binary:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/b44540a41efceeef4fd08d8064b6a9b6.js"></script></p>
<p>We thought that <span style="font-family: monospace">IfYouAreReadingThisYouHaveTooMuchFreeTime</span> is an easter egg for us, malware analysts, but it turns out that it&#8217;s just a strange quirk related to <a href="https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/perfdude/2008/07/06/ifyouarereadingthisyouhavetoomuchfreetime/">hotmail authentication</a>.</p>
<p>Configuration for this module, fetched from C&#038;C:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/0a2d00bdbe9a97992579a61b36882181.js"></script></p>
<h2>13. blist.dll</h2>
<p>This plugin checks if a bot is listed as a spambot and blacklisted. In the config we observed following DNSBLs (DNS-based Blackhole Lists) were supplied:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/bc6f643db4688dd0130a22c409edc987.js"></script></p>
<p>DNSBL is a service based on DNS used for publishing IP addresses of spam senders. If spam server uses DNSBL filters, it will do a DNS request to DNSBL domain with each incoming SMTP connection. Technical details are outside of the scope of this post, but any interested reader can take a look at <a href="http://www.us.sorbs.net/using.shtml">http://www.us.sorbs.net/using.shtml</a> or <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DNSBL">https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DNSBL</a>.</p>
<p>Checking DNSBL is implemented with gethostbyname:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/076064abf7b59a5d3611682265b25665.js"></script></p>
<p>Configuration for this module, fetched from C&#038;C:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/9af2321b33ccc33fd892c1f25baf800f.js"></script></p>
<h2>14. miner.dll</h2>
<p>This is (as the name suggests) cryptocurrency miner. This plugin only coordinates the work, but  it has few accompanying binaries, that perform the dirty work.</p>
<p>One binary, called grabb, is distributed straight from the C&#038;C. Other binaries are downloadable through URLs specified in configs &#8211; in theory. In practice, servers distributing miners seem to be dead, so we were not able to download miners.</p>
<p>Miner &#8220;verifies&#8221; that has really downloaded right binary, but hashing was probably too difficult for malware creators to implement, so they settled on size verification &#8211; for example, they are check that <span style="font-family: monospace">cores_gt_1</span> binary has exactly 223744 bytes.</p>
<p>We didn&#8217;t analyze it in-depth because crypto miners are boring enough, and strings from binary give enough information about inner workings anyway:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/b7db7bec5bd8f32e648c249661132407.js"></script></p>
<p>And the rest can be read from the configuration, fetched from C&#038;C:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/7f1271e4ff315b3a1d24567855da730c.js"></script></p>
<h2>15. img.dll</h2>
<p>This short plugin processes malicious attachments &#8211; encodes them with base64 and appends to emails.</p>
<p>Nothing interesting here, as can be seen in hardcoded strings:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/fcd5542ffe9f23e2de8e15084e36366e.js"></script></p>
<p>Configuration for this module, fetched from the C&#038;C:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/ba1b98ca203eda5ae54a5449d9acf0e8.js"></script></p>
<h2>16. spread.dll</h2>
<p>This plugin is used to spread Tofsee through social media: Facebook, Twitter and Skype communicator.</p>
<p>First, it extracts <span style="font-family: monospace">xs</span>, <span style="font-family: monospace">datr</span>, <span style="font-family: monospace">c_user</span> (and more) cookies.</p>
<p>Exact method depends on the browser, but generally plugin reads cookies stored on disk by the browser &#8211; for example <span style="font-family: monospace">cookies.sqlite</span> from <span style="font-family: monospace">\Mozilla\Firefox\Profiles</span>, for Firefox. Supported browsers are Chrome, IE, Firefox, Safari, and Opera.</p>
<p>After that, plugin uses that cookies to impersonate user in facebook API:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/ef32a3d460b3af144e54ebd2f6f341e4.js"></script></p>
<p>List of friends is downloaded through API and a message is sent to them. Format of message is stored in configuration, for example:</p>
<p><span style="font-family: monospace">&#8216;fb.message1&#8217;: &#8216;%SPRD_TEXT1|%LANG_ID| %SPRD_URL1&#8217;</span></p>
<p>Twitter is handled very similarly: cookies are stolen, followers are downloaded by API call to <span style="font-family: monospace">https://twitter.com/followers</span>, and messages are sent.</p>
<p><span style="font-family: monospace">VKontakte</span> also seems to be supported, but that functionality is optional and held in another plugin. This module only checks if VK is enabled in config and calls handler (that can be initialized from another plugin), if it&#8217;s defined. Malware creators usually don&#8217;t like to attack Russia, so this function is disabled and VKontakte plugin is not distributed.</p>
<p>Plugin can also spread itself through Skype, but reverse engineering Skype protocol was clearly too hard for malware authors, so plugin waits until Skype is started, and then sends windows messages to Skype window:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/49042af9a10277defe1ff39e1ed9c0d1.js"></script></p>
<p>The plugin has dozens of strings hardcoded, so analyzing it in disassembler is a breeze. Few more interesting groups:</p>
<p>References to the OCR plugin &#8211; to avoid captchas:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/a69b4214527721c34dabf6adcc389ab0.js"></script></p>
<p>Facebook cookies:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/bdce2cfdd8a4ce65898e5fe4c3b85fad.js"></script></p>
<p>Strings related to Facebook spread:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/03bff667315a67289f57ba3a65947216.js"></script></p>
<p>Strings related to cookie stealing:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/5228b5024c7099e78802d925c888d61a.js"></script></p>
<p>Strings related to Skype hijacking:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/2c53b0283114d14fc752ee2749d214c0.js"></script></p>
<p>Twitter cookies:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/94ce278c4f0d806df668f9bd54056819.js"></script></p>
<p>And Twitter spread:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/56f62f1f044b2be6f321aaf2c316a221.js"></script></p>
<p>Finally, things needed to send stolen cookies somewhere:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/769485c15ea76c79d172e5fe468ca492.js"></script></p>
<p>Rich functionality means rich configuration from the C&#038;C:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/7cfa61c1fc1e587b0f8f67e4fe2ccf5d.js"></script></p>
<h2>17. spread2.dll</h2>
<p>This plugin uses methods more than 15 years old, and tries to spread Tofsee through&#8230; infected USB drives! This doesn&#8217;t sound like an effective idea for A.D. 2017, but despite that, the plugin is still enabled.</p>
<p>First it copies malicious binary into <span style="font-family: monospace">RECYCLER\&lt;random_gibberish&gt;.exe</span> file on the USB drive, then sets READONLY and SYSTEM attributes on that file, and finally writes malicious autorun.inf file:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/a3bb8498b3cb8a062b37e756098016d5.js"></script></p>
<p>The malicious binary that will be spread is downloaded from the internet (see also sys.dll plugin and <span style="font-family: monospace">%FIREURL</span> variable).</p>
<p>Nothing too interesting in hardcoded strings, except operation logs:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/66cc852343c12d4170c5cfb1d1a9cc97.js"></script></p>
<p>Configuration for this module, fetched from the C&#038;C:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/458a7597aed7aa601a214570be50bf1b.js"></script></p>
<h2>18. sys.dll</h2>
<p>This plugin seems to be a downloader or rather an updater. It sends requests, depending on a value of the <span style="font-family: monospace">%FIREURL</span> configuration variable.</p>
<p>Example values of the <span style="font-family: monospace">%FIREURL</span> variable (one per line):</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/b9005d309767d680caeeda0396bc96ff.js"></script></p>
<p>Variables are expanded recursively, and <span style="font-family: monospace">%SYS_RN</span> means <span style="font-family: monospace">\r\n</span> of course, so first possible value can be read as:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/c30d16fdb9aead83107b0d8d387e2bf2.js"></script></p>
<p>If we send this request to that IP address on port 80, we will get yet another malicious binary. Different requests lead to different binaries.</p>
<p>If a request is invalid, or not supported, following image is sent instead:</p>
<p><img src="../../../../uploads/2017/10/fakeimage.jpg" alt=""></p>
<p>We appreciate the humor.</p>
<p>Nothing surprising in hardcoded strings:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/f71052f33dfbbc5f5e812f0b9e6d6adc.js"></script></p>
<p>Configuration for this module, fetched from the C&#038;C:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/1f013ce756cb89a8f9d64aa738ca4358.js"></script></p>
<p>Additionally the <span style="font-family: monospace">%FIREURL</span> variable from config is used.</p>
<h2>19. webb.dll</h2>
<p>This plugin tries to locate <span style="font-family: monospace">iexplore.exe</span> process. If this succeeds, it injects DLL file called <span style="font-family: monospace">IEStub.dll</span> to this process.</p>
<p><span style="font-family: monospace">IEStub.dll</span> hooks a lot of functions from iexplorer. List of hooked functions:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/745a5d5fd1020f822a72356a78f5fd5b.js"></script></p>
<p>Hooks intercept called functions and can change their parameters. We haven&#8217;t analyzed hooks in depth, but most of them seem to be loggers intercepting &#8220;interesting&#8221; data from parameters &#8211; We haven&#8217;t observed any web injects served by Tofsee.</p>
<p>For completeness, interesting hardcoded strings:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/2342ef43fcad256aeb402545a7678bc4.js"></script></p>
<p>Configuration for this module, fetched from the C&#038;C:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/e958eb1002e2b7f297f7b457cd8b51e2.js"></script></p>
<h2>20. P2P.dll</h2>
<p>Original filename: <span style="font-family: monospace">p:\cmf5\small2\plugins\plg_p2p\plg_p2p.cpp</span></p>
<p>This plugin is rather short. Despite promising name, it&#8217;s rather boring &#8211; opening a port on a router and listening for connection is the most important thing it does. It doesn&#8217;t implement any commands, this is left for the main module to handle.</p>
<p>Like almost every module, it logs to <span style="font-family: monospace">%TMP%\log_%s.txt</span>, and when this fails falls back to <span style="font-family: monospace">C:\log.txt</span>.</p>
<p>Also adds port mapping using UPnP, in the same way as plugin 4 (<span style="font-family: monospace">proxyR.dll</span>).</p>
<p>Configuration for this module, fetched from the C&#038;C:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/cd64f338c460c47c42199eca12207ac2.js"></script></p>
<p>Interesting strings:</p>
<p><script src="https://gist.github.com/efabfe2e9ff4132b66a662551facdb76.js"></script></p>
